name: Great Dane
healthissues: Bloat, hip issues, heart issues, wobbler disease, merle gene issues
Blurb: Contrary to its name, the Great Dane does not actually originate from Denmark, rather, they actually originated in Germany. Great Danes are a very large breed of dog, there are very few larger than them so keep that in mind before deciding to get one. Due to their size it’s not uncommon for them to be chosen as guard dogs. However, this does not mean they have a bad temper, unlike certain other dog breeds.

name: Siberian Husky
healthissues: Eye and hip issues
blurb: Siberian Huskies are generally very sociable, friendly, and energetic dogs, they certainly needed to be for their role of sled dogs used in big teams in Siberia. Siberian Huskies popularity truly took off all the way back in 1925 where one man and a group of dogs made a 658 mile journey in a mere five and a half days to deliver medicine. This was such a big deal that the lead dog maintains a statue in Central Park in New York City to this day.

name: Bernese Mountain Dog
healthissues: Elbow, eye, hip, and heart issues
blurb: This breed is the definition of a gentle giant. Their job in their home of Switzerland was one that should be unsurprising given their size, guarding farms and helping move heavy loads, and they certainly succeeded in that job both there and when they were imported into the US in the early 1900’s.

name: Alaskan Malamute
healthissues: Eye, hip, and polyneuropathy issues
blurb: The Alaskan Malamute is to the Siberian Husky as a pickup truck is to a sports car. The Malamute is named after an Inuit tribe of similar name and was bred to help move significantly larger loads. Since World War Two this breed of dog has seen a rather heavy drop in population.

name: Labrador Retriever
healthissues: Obesity
blurb: Labradors are one of the staple pictures of a friendly, high-energy family dog. You will be hard pressed to find a more friendly breed of dog than this. Of course this also means that you should be ready to be able to deal with all of that energy lest they start to spend that energy on things such as your furniture.

name: Cocker Spaniel
healthissues: Eye and hip issues
blurb: If you see a short dog with an especially long and fancy coat then odds are you’re looking at a Cocker Spaniel. This breed took off in popularity in the US back in the 40’s and 50’s for both a combination of their unique coat and great attitudes.

name: Brittany
healthissues: Eye and hip issues
blurb: Just by looking at a Brittany you can tell that it was developed first and foremost as a hunting dog. This was developed by those who lived out in the countryside in France and needed a solid and reliable hunting dog and they maintain this status and success today as well. As such it’s important to remember that the Brittany is not an indoor dog and should be taken outside for exercise regularly.

name: English Setter
healthissues: Ear, hip, and thyroid issues
blurb: Like the other sporting dogs, the Englisher Setter was developed as a hunter’s assistant. The Setter name comes from what they were designated to do, that is to set. Specifically, they would be taken out to find game birds and would lie down when they had found some.

name: Dalmatian
origin: Unknown, most closely associated with Dalmatia
healthissues: Deafness, allergies, urinary stones

name: Bulldog
healthissues: Possible overheating, may see tongue stick out too far with a bluish cast.
blurb: Bulldogs are an unmistakable breed of dog with a face that shows courage and determination. This stems from the 13th century in England when the ancestors of bulldogs fought a bull in the sport of “bullbaiting”. Bulldogs are also very docile, but it is advised to have bulldogs spend more time in an air-conditioned room during the Summer since their short snouts may force them to breathe more when the weather gets hot and humid.

name: Poodle
healthissues: Hip dysplasia, eye disorders, idiopathic epilepsy, sebaceous adenitis, von Willebrand’s disease, immune-mediated disorders
blurb: Despite the fact that the poodle is the national dog of France, they actually originated in Germany as duck hunters. Poodles are incredibly smart and their coat allows them to swim very well in the water as well as protecting them from certain things like the cold. Poodles also come in three different size varieties known as Standard, Miniature, and Toy. In France, poodles were known for being excellent entertainers.

name: Keeshond
healthissues: Hip and elbow dysplasia, patellar luxation, hyperparathyroidism
blurb: The Keeshond breed seems to have some mystery behind it since the exact origin is unclear, although they did serve as guard dogs on Dutch ships, and that there is no clear reason why the breed was named “Keeshond”. These dogs have special markings around their face that make it look like it’s wearing spectacles, this shows that the Keeshond is intelligent to go with his amiable personality.

name: German Shepard
healthissues: Hip and spine issues as well as arthritis
blurb: Contrary to what they are primarily used for nowadays (police dogs, guard dogs, etc.), they actually originated as a shepherding dog. Since the breed is so recent as well, we even know the specific person who set about creating this breed, one Max von Stephanitz, a German cavalry officer in the 1800’s.

name: Pembroke Welsh Corgi
healthissues: Hip and elbow dysplasia, eye disorders, cardiac issues, degenerative myelopathy, von Willebrand’s disease
blurb: In the past, King Henry I of Britain invited some of the best weavers from Flanders (now Northern Belgium) to come to southwestern Wales. The weavers brought their dogs with them too and eventually, the dogs were named after the place where they worked, Pembrokeshire. Being cattle herding dogs in the past made corgis very athletic, alert, and fearless, and they enjoy being active with their families.

name: Border Collie
healthissues: Hip dysplasia, progressive renal atrophy, deafness, epilepsy, collie eye anomaly, neuronal ceroid lipofuscinosis, trapped neutrophil syndrome
blurb: During the times of the Roman Empire, the Border Collies emerged when Roman dogs were crossed with dogs that Viking raiders brought with them during Britain’s invasion. Border Collies are considered the greatest herders in the world with their athleticism, energy, and intelligence. Border Collies show their friendly nature around their friends but are rather quiet around strangers.

name: Icelandic Sheepdog
healthissues: Hip and elbow dysplasia, patellar luxation
blurb: Icelandic Sheepdogs were brought from Norway to Iceland by Norse settlers a long time ago. Icelandic Sheepdogs are a national symbol to Iceland and are also classified as spitzes, they can also come in different colors with white markings and a very friendly face.

name: Bloodhound
healthissues: Gastrointestinal (Hereafter referred to as bloat), eye, skin, and ear issues. Beware of overheating due to the thick coat.
blurb: Bloodhounds are one of those instantly recognizable breeds with their unmistakable face. They are commonly seen in police departments and the like for their world renowned nose, being able to follow almost any trail and for extended periods of time. They tend towards being much more laid-back and independent than other dogs, certainly nowhere near as energetic as breeds such as the Labrador Retriever. *While the modern Bloodhound can be generally said to have originated out of Western Europe the origin of the breed as a whole is unknown, though it is possible it could have existed as far back as the 3rd century in the Roman Empire.

name: Dachshund
healthissues: Knee and heart issues
blurb: The stereotype of small dogs being crazy energetic may be untrue with some dog breeds but the Dachsund is not one of them. These very short and very long dogs have an absolutely unmistakable appearance but it is for good reason. They were developed for the exact reason their name suggests as translated from the German it is in, it means Badger Dog and with that context their shape, and aggressiveness, makes a lot more sense.

name: Greyhound
healthissues: Eye, heart, and NDRG1 polyneuropathy disease
blurb: Don’t be alarmed if the Greyhound looks familiar as if you’ve ever been in a history class that has gone over Egyptian hieroglyphs or watched a history documentary on them you may very well have seen ancient pictures of this dog. As their form may suggest they are fantastic sprinters and were used for catching fast animals.

name: Beagle
healthissues: Eye, hip, heart, and thyroid issues
blurb: Beagles made their name as general purpose small animal hunters. In this role they received the nickname of foot hound in reference to being able to walk and keep up with them on foot rather than requiring horseback to keep up with as in the case of some larger and faster dogs.

name: Bull Terrier
healthissues: Kidney and heart issues
history: Bull Terriers have an unfortunate history of being born out of dogfighting rings in England. As a result, while not being particularly large they do tend to be fairly strong for their size. Also, while breeders have largely mellowed out their temper since their creation in the 1800’s it is still not recommended to have them around other dogs. As with everything this is not an absolute, each dog is different after all, but do keep this in mind.

name: Scottish Terrier
healthissues: Knee issues and Von Willebrand’s disease (blood not clotting)

name: Border Terrier
healthissues: Eye, heart, hip, and knee issues

name: Rat Terrier
healthissues: Eye, heart, hip, and knee issues

name: Pug
healthissues: Breathing and overheating issues
blurb: Pugs are a lot of love in a small bundle, something you can thank ancient Chinese emperors for cultivating. Similarly to Labradors, Pugs are a great dog for the family but in a much smaller and more easily handled size.

name: Chihuahua
healthissues: Potential heart problems, eye disease, patellar luxation(loose kneecaps), idiopathic epilepsy
blurb: The chihuahua is known as one of the oldest dog breeds in America. A pre-Columbian culture known as the Toltecs had a larger, heavier ancestor of the chihuahua known as a Techichi, but these dogs were refined to be smaller and lighter after the Aztecs took over the Toltecs in the 12th century. Chihuahuas are perfect city pets due to their small size, and they are quite confident, clever, loyal, and charming despite their size.

name: Shih Tzu
healthissues: Hip dysplasia, patellar luxation, inflammation from too much exposure to air due when eyelids don’t close correctly.
blurb: Shih Tzus are some of the most refined, affectionate, and well-groomed breed of dogs known. This stems from Chinese history when Shih Tzu lived in palaces with the emperors, being pampered and sitting in their owner’s lap. The Shih Tzu breed is very affectionate, especially with children, and they prefer to be inside rather than play outside.

name: Silky Terrier
healthissues: Patellar luxation, eye disease
blurb: The Silky Terrier is often mistaken for an Australian or Yorkshire terrier since the Silky Terriers first emerged when those two breeds (along with other possible terriers brought to Australia) were crossed. The Silky Terrier has a special blue-and-tan glossy coat and is considered very energetic, though a bit more refined than most terriers, but despite that it has “Terrier” in its name it’s actually in the “Toy” group due to its small size
